title: Llys y Fran Reservoir Country Park Walking and Cycle Route

images.title: Garth Newton / Llys-y-fran Reservoir and Country Park
images.caption: Llys-y-fran Reservoir and Country Park. There is a visitor centre on the site with a restaurant and a gift shop and many outdoor events are organised throughout the year. In this picture you can see the information board and the reservoir behind. Taken on a glorious summer day in 2001.

images.title: ceridwen / Llys-y-fran reservoir from the dam
images.caption: A view of the reservoir from the dam in the spring of 2007. The 200 acre reservoir was built between 1968 and 72 to provide water for south Pembrokeshire and the oil industry. Provision was made to increase the capacity of the reservoir if necessary but although this was not done, a few years ago a 20% increase was achieved by raising the levels of the outflows. The reservoir is used for recreational purposes including fishing, boating and walking around the circumference.

images.title: Tudor Williams / Llys-y-fran reservoir
images.caption: A view of the reservoir taken from the car park on the far side of the dam

images.title: ceridwen / Millstones, Llys-y-fran
images.caption: Millstones in the village of Llys-y-fran, April 2007. The village of Llys-y-fran with its church and a cluster of houses and farms is easily missed by visitors to the adjacent country park and reservoir. This farm entrance with its old millstones and spacious barn dates from a time when agriculture was profitable and tourism unheard-of. Llys-y-fran means court of the raven (or crow, or rook).

images.title: ceridwen / Mixed woodland at Llys-y-fran
images.caption: Mixed woodland at the park. At the top end of the country park the deciduous woodland around the reservoir changes to a mixture with larch and other conifers dominating. The footpath leads out to a minor road from Castell Hendre/Henry's Moat.

description: This 350 acre country park contains a beautiful 212 acre reservoir with a waterside cycling and walking path. The park includes grassland and woodland with cycle hire available in the park. As well as the 6.5 mile reservoir perimeter track, there is also a 1.5 mile trail suitable for families. In 2020 the site has been extensivley redeveloped with a new visitor centre refurbishment, new outdoor activity centre and waterside cabin, bike pump skills area and new cycle tracks offering over 14km of trails to explore.
